Tasks.Task Description: Gather detailed requirements for containerized applications, including scalability, availability, and resource needs. Identify the services and workloads to be deployed on Azure Service Fabric.
Design the cluster architecture, including node types, durability levels, and placement constraints. Plan for high availability and fault tolerance.
Create and configure the Service Fabric cluster in the Azure portal or using Azure CLI/PowerShell. Ensure proper configuration of node types and VM sizes.
Set up networking for the Service Fabric cluster, including virtual networks, subnets, and load balancers. Ensure secure communication between nodes and external services.
Package and deploy containerized applications to the Service Fabric cluster. Use Docker images and ensure proper configuration of application parameters.
Enable security features such as certificate-based authentication, encryption for data in transit, and access control policies. Configure Azure Key Vault for managing secrets.
Configure monitoring and diagnostics using Azure Monitor and Application Insights. Set up alerts for cluster health, node status, and application performance.
Perform thorough testing of the cluster and deployed applications, including failover scenarios, load testing, and performance benchmarking.
Create detailed documentation for the cluster setup, application deployment, and operational procedures. Include troubleshooting guides and escalation paths.
Provide training sessions for the operations team on managing and troubleshooting the Service Fabric cluster and containerized applications.
Ensure the cluster and applications meet regulatory compliance requirements. Set up regular auditing procedures to verify security and operational standards.

Use Azure Monitor and Service Fabric Explorer to continuously monitor the health and status of the Service Fabric cluster hosting containers. Identify and investigate any anomalies or potential issues.
Regularly update container images to ensure they include the latest security patches and performance improvements. Use Azure Container Registry or other repositories for image management.
Ensure that containers are allocated sufficient resources (CPU, memory, etc.) within the Service Fabric cluster. Adjust resource limits as needed to optimize performance.
Upgrade the Service Fabric cluster to the latest version to ensure compatibility with container workloads and access to new features.
Regularly back up the Service Fabric cluster configuration and container deployment settings to ensure quick recovery in case of failure.
Review and update security policies for containers running in Service Fabric, including access controls and encryption settings.
Conduct failover tests to ensure container workloads can recover seamlessly in case of node or cluster failures.
Analyze container placement within the Service Fabric cluster to ensure optimal distribution and performance. Adjust placement constraints as needed.
Perform regular incident response drills to prepare the team for potential security incidents or container workload outages.
Analyze container logs for errors, warnings, or performance issues. Use Azure Monitor or other logging tools for detailed insights.
Ensure that networking configurations for containers, such as DNS and IP routing, are functioning correctly within the Service Fabric cluster.
Develop and execute plans for scaling container workloads within the Service Fabric cluster based on usage trends and forecasts.
